Here‚Äôs what can be done to ensure that COVID-19 doesn‚Äôt collapse the restaurant industry: 

‚û°Ô∏èPass a form of the RESTAURANTS Act

‚û°Ô∏èDeliver credit to low- and moderate-income Americans via CDFIs and MDIs

‚û°Ô∏èIncrease the EITC, especially for workers without children

Congress took an important step at the end of last year with the passage of a COVID-19 relief package that included hundreds of billions of dollars for businesses. 

More is needed.

IMPORTANT: The struggles of the restaurant industry during the COVID-19 crisis are especially concerning given the important role that it plays for the economic livelihoods of women, people of color and immigrants.

51% of restaurant workers are employed by businesses with fewer than 100 employees and 64% work for businesses with fewer than 500 employees. 

Small-businesses typically lack the cash reserves and access to credit needed to survive a months-long loss of revenue. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EryhpqNXIAIC9Ay.png

The situation facing restaurants is unlikely to improve this winter as COVID-19 cases surge. 

This fall, as cases increased, indoor dining decreased. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EryhkM9XIAExDBD.png
In December, there were 2.5 million fewer workers (a 20% reduction) employed in food services and drinking places than in February. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eryhd7LXcAAcmh5.png

The restaurant industry has been devastated by COVID-19. 

Despite accounting for less than 1 in 10 jobs in the U.S. economy before the pandemic, the restaurant industry has accounted for about one in four jobs lost during the pandemic.
